dc:description:
COL1A1 has been described in relation to autosomal dominant Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) Type I-IV. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found difference in clinical phenotypic presentation and molecular mechanism between OI Types I-IV. Therefore, the following disease entities have been split: OI Type I (OMIM: 166200), OI Type II (OMIM: 166210), OI Type III (OMIM: 259420), and OI Type IV (OMIM: 166220). OI Type II is also known as lethal OI, and is characterized by bone fragility, perinatal fractures, severe bowing of long bones, blue sclerae in some cases, undermineralization, and death in the perinatal period due to respiratory insufficiency (Sillence et al. 1979; PMID: 458828). COL1A1 variants associated with OI Type II are not always 100% predictive of the disease because of genetic modifiers, and therefore long term survival and involvement in other types of OI can be seen with certain variants implicated in this disease. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level and experimental data. At least 18 unique variants (missense, in-frame deletions and duplications, and one frameshift variant not predicted to cause NMD) have been identified in OI Type II patients in 10 publications (PMIDs: 21834035, 3016737, 3108247, 7679635, 8100209, 7487936, 22795119, 25958000, 11668615, 25289482). This gene-disease association is also supported by a mouse model that is compatible with the disease phenotypes, but is not a definitive model due to its use of transgene methodology (PMID: 2450280). In summary, COL1A1 is definitively associated with autosomal dominant Osteogenesis Imperfecta Type II. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This curation was approved by the Skeletal Disorders Gene Curation Expert Panel (GCEP) on 3/3/2021.
Gene Clinical Validity Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) - Version 8.

evidence.dc:description: Scored as a de novo variant (arising de novo in mosaic father) with supporting radiographs, in patient with consistent phenotypes = 1 pt.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2.1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Presented at birth with bowing of lower limbs, hypoplastic thorax, dysmorphic facial features: micrognathia, triangular face. Radiographs: wormian bones of the skull, slender long bones and ribs, with multiple fractures, dense transverse bands in metaphyses and fracture surfaces of the long bones, respiratory distress requiring a ventilation support, and died at age 4 months.

evidence.dc:description: Confirmed de novo variant in patient with consistent phenotypes and with functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: MacKay Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Genomic DNA from fibroblast of proband and parents, PCR to amplify region, SSCP to identify. Absent from parents.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Presented at birth with short bowed extremities, dark blue sclerae, and soft skull. Died 15 minutes after birth.

evidence.dc:description: De novo variant in individual with consistent phenotypes, radiograph, and functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cohn/Steinmann Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Sanger of 2kb region of patient's DNA containing COL1A1 variant- cysteine residue. Confirmed absence in parents.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: generalized growth impairment, transverse presentation, soft head, blue sclerae, short bowed legs, low set dysmorphic ears, short neck, hypoplasia of external genitalia, broad, crumpled, bowed long bones, beaded wavy ribs and clavicles, generalized osteopenia, unusual rectangular iliac bones, hypoplasia of epiglottis, ventricular septal defect, open foramen ovale, patent ductus, pyeloureteral stenosis on the right, and abdominal testes, soft/lax/friable joint capsules of hips and knees.

evidence.dc:description: Confirmed de novo variant in patient with consistent phenotypes and radiograph.

evidence.rdfs:label: Chen Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Molecular analysis of COL1A1 and COL1A2 of proband and parents. Variant absent from parents. Mother has short stature but no COL1A1/2 variants.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Presented at 24 weeks gestation with shortening, angulation and crumpled appearance of long bones, small chest with beading of ribs, skull deformation and hypomineralization with too-well-seen brain structure. Pregnancy was terminated. Radiograph: generalized osteopenia, decreased mineralization of the skull, and abnormal tubular bones with thin cortex and shafts, callus formation and fractures.

evidence.dc:description: Confirmed de novo variant in patient with consistent phenotypes.

evidence.rdfs:label: Maasalu Proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Presented at birth with totally soft skull, large and flat head collapsed from front to back direction, bones in occipital region were not palpable, exophthalmia, blue sclerae, disproportional growth impairment with short, bowed arms and legs, both hips were hyperflexed and turned outward.

evidence.dc:description: De novo variant in patient with consistent phenotypes and with radiographs, but no functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.detectionMethod: PCR and direct sequencing of COL1A1, COL1A2, LEPRE1, CRTAP, PPIB
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: At birth: short bent limbs with long fingers and toes, multiple fractures of the long bones, hypoplastic thorax/thoracic cage, relative macrocephaly with caput membraneceum, triangular face with hypertelorism, protruding eyes, and low set, malformed ears, died shortly after birth. Postmortem radiographs: severe calvarial demineralization, small dense facial bones, dense skull base, clavicles and ribs with discontinuous beading and multiple fractures, slender twisted diaphyses of long bones, flared metaphyses of long bones with dense transverse bonds, broad gap and sclerosis of the fracture surfaces resembled those of pseudoarthrosis, irregular/sclerotic scapular, ischial, and iliac margins.

evidence.dc:description: Variant with functional evidence of impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Valli Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Skin fibroblasts from proband, unaffected parents and sister, and one healthy control.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Presented at birth with short and bowed  legs, severe flexed and abducted hips, blue sclerae, wide fontanellae, soft skull. Radiographs (not shown): poor calvarial mineralization, hypoplasia of cranial bones, generalized osteopenia, bilateral fractures of  femoral heads, thinning of long bones, S-shaped femurs and bowing of tibiae. Died at 18 months following respiratory failure.

evidence.dc:description: Variant has functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Culbert Proband 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Tentative OI2 diagnosis made at 18 weeks gestation based on ultrasounds. Full diagnosis based on consistent phenotypes in radiographs (not shown) at birth. Died 2 hours after birth.

evidence.dc:description: Functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Pace Patient 5
evidence.detectionMethod: Overlapping fragments of COL1A1 and COL1A2 were amplified, then Sanger to confirm variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: short, compressed tubular bones, marked diminution of calvarial mineralization, beaded ribs, varying platyspondyly, and death in the perinatal period

evidence.dc:description: Consistent phenotypes with radiographs.

evidence.rdfs:label: Wu Patient F5
evidence.detectionMethod: "Qualified genomic DNA fragments were randomly interrupted" and fragments were amplified with PCR before high throughput sequencing and analysis (Illumina).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: under mineralization of the calvarium, ribs with multiple fractures in a discontinuous beading pattern with normal rib parts in between callus formation, long bones of the lower extremities are broadened, deformed and shortened as a result of multiple fractures.

evidence.dc:description: Functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Pace Patient 3
evidence.detectionMethod: Overlapping fragments of COL1A1 and COL1A2 were amplified, then Sanger to confirm variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: short, compressed tubular bones, marked diminution of calvarial mineralization, beaded ribs, varying platyspondyly, and death in the perinatal period

evidence.dc:description: Functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Pace Patient 2
evidence.detectionMethod: Overlapping fragments of COL1A1 and COL1A2 were amplified, then Sanger to confirm variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: short, compressed tubular bones, marked diminution of calvarial mineralization, beaded ribs, varying platyspondyly, and death in the perinatal period

evidence.dc:description: Variant has functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Culbert Proband 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Evaluation at 32 weeks revealed short limbs in ultrasound. Full OI2 diagnosis based on consistent phenotypes in radiographs (not shown) at birth. Died in immediate perinatal period.

evidence.dc:description: No radiographs nor specific clinical report, but extensive supporting functional evidence.

evidence.rdfs:label: Bateman Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Tissue samples from patient's autopsy and skin biopsies from parents. Peptide sequencing and amino acid analysis.

evidence.dc:description: Functional evidence supporting impact.

evidence.rdfs:label: Pace Patient 4
evidence.detectionMethod: Overlapping fragments of COL1A1 and COL1A2 were amplified, then Sanger to confirm variant.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: short, compressed tubular bones, marked diminution of calvarial mineralization, beaded ribs, varying platyspondyly, and death in the perinatal period

evidence.dc:description: Consistent phenotypes with radiographs.

evidence.rdfs:label: Wu Patient F2
evidence.detectionMethod: "Qualified genomic DNA fragments were randomly interrupted" and fragments were amplified with PCR before high throughput sequencing and analysis (Illumina).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: under mineralization of the calvarium, ribs with multiple fractures in a discontinuous beading pattern with normal rib parts in between callus formation, long bones of the lower extremities are broadened, deformed and shortened as a result of multiple fractures.

evidence.dc:description: Consistent phenotypes with radiographs.

evidence.rdfs:label: Wu Patient F4
evidence.detectionMethod: "Qualified genomic DNA fragments were randomly interrupted" and fragments were amplified with PCR before high throughput sequencing and analysis (Illumina).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: under mineralization of the calvarium, ribs with multiple fractures in a discontinuous beading pattern with normal rib parts in between callus formation, long bones of the lower extremities are broadened, deformed and shortened as a result of multiple fractures.

evidence.dc:description: Consistent phenotypes with radiographs.

evidence.rdfs:label: Wu Patient F3
evidence.detectionMethod: "Qualified genomic DNA fragments were randomly interrupted" and fragments were amplified with PCR before high throughput sequencing and analysis (Illumina).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: under mineralization of the calvarium, ribs with multiple fractures in a discontinuous beading pattern with normal rib parts in between callus formation, long bones of the lower extremities are broadened, deformed and shortened as a result of multiple fractures.

evidence.dc:description: Compatible phenotypes but not a definitive model due to transgene methodology.

7 fetuses of 9 that died shortly before/after birth carried transgene. These fetuses were pliable, with abnormally flexible limbs, soft skull. Radiographs: short and wavy ribs, short and broad long bones, poor mineralization. The skull, rib, and long bone abnormalities and poor mineralization and death in perinatal period are characteristic of OI2 in humans.
evidence.rdfs:label: Stacey Mouse Model
